symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
Thrombocytosis secondary to iron deficiency anemia

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis
diagnoses.description: A rare but potentially fatal disorder caused by excessive activation of macrophages and lymphocytes, leading to severe hyperinflammation. It can present with fever, hyperferritinemia, cytopenias (such as leukopenia), hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect nearly any part of the body, leading to widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs. Miscarriage, leukopenia, and lymphadenopathy are common symptoms, along with arthritis, rash, and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also have systemic manifestations including hyperferritinemia due to inflammation, leukopenia as part of Felty's syndrome, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) leads to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS), characterized by a progressive failure of the immune system. Symptoms can include leukopenia due to destruction of T cells, lymphadenopathy, and an increased risk of miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it presents with fever, sore throat, fatigue, and lymphadenopathy. Leukopenia can occur early in the illness, followed by lymphocytosis. Miscarriage risk could be indirectly increased due to high fevers or the body's strain from fighting the infection.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A group of blood cancers that develop in the lymph system. The primary symptoms include enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy), fevers, unintended weight loss, and night sweats. Anemia and leukopenia can occur if bone marrow is affected.

diagnoses.name: Anemia of Chronic Disease
diagnoses.description: A type of anemia that occurs in chronic infections, inflammatory diseases, and malignancies. It can be associated with hyperferritinemia as part of the inflammatory process. Leukopenia may also be present.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory arthritis characterized by high fevers, salmon-colored rash, and arthritis. Hyperferritinemia is a notable lab finding, and some patients present with leukopenia and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that form lumps known as granulomas. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and fever. Hyperferritinemia can also be present due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by the abnormal proliferation of immune cells, leading to autoimmune phenomena. Manifestations include lymphadenopathy, autoimmunity (causing potential miscarriage), and hematological abnormalities including leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, and your body doesn't have enough water and other fluids to carry out its normal functions; can cause xerosis and can indirectly affect oral health.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth; can lead to xerosis, periodontal disease due to lack of saliva, and may complicate laryngitis due to dryness.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear; can manifest as pseudoseizures in some cases, and may exacerbate or contribute to periodontal disease through stress.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Lack of certain vitamins, such as vitamin A, B, C, D can lead to various health issues including xerosis (skin dryness), periodontal disease, and overall weakened immune system potentially affecting the larynx.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones; can cause dry skin (xerosis), and may influence the occurrence of periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness; pseudoseizures may be present as psychogenic non-epileptic seizures.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: The gradual loss of kidney function; can cause xerosis due to build-up of toxins affecting the skin, and contribute to oral health problems.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk, and scalp; 'tags' could refer to skin tags associated with skin conditions.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose); can cause xerosis, and is a risk factor for periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or, occasionally, stomach content, flows back into your esophagus; 'laryngitis' can be a symptom due to acid reflux, and periodontal disease can be an associated condition.

diagnoses: Vitamin Deficiency (e.g., Vitamin B12, Vitamin D)
Secondary Immunodeficiency due to Medication or Illness
Dermatological conditions related to systemic diseases
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and related disorders
Autoimmune disorders with neurological and dermatological manifestations
Endocrine disorders with neurological and cutaneous manifestations
Nutritional deficiencies leading to skin and neurological symptoms
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Acquired angioedema (e.g., due to ACE inhibitors)

diagnoses.details: A stroke might manifest with symptoms like aphasia, weakness on one side of the body, headache, and visual disturbances including diplopia.
Migraines can sometimes present with an aura, including visual phenomena such as scintillations, along with headache, speech disturbances, and other neurological symptoms.
A TIA, often called a 'mini-stroke', can temporarily present symptoms like aphasia, diplopia, and weakness, resolving within 24 hours.
Depending on its location, a brain tumor can cause a wide range of symptoms including headache, aphasia, visual disturbances, and weakness.
MS is a chronic autoimmune disorder affecting the CNS, potentially causing diplopia, weakness, and, in some cases, language disturbances.
A localized infection in the brain can produce symptoms depending on its location, potentially including headache, aphasia, and visual disturbances.
An aneurysm in the brain can cause severe headaches, visual symptoms like diplopia, and if rupturing, may lead to stroke-like symptoms including weakness and aphasia.
Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection, which can cause headache, aphasia, weakness, and sometimes visual disturbances.
Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, commonly caused by an infection, leading to severe headache, and possibly affecting nerve function, causing symptoms like weakness and aphasia.
In cases of complex partial seizures, individuals may experience transient aphasia, and during a postictal state, experience headache, confusion, and other symptoms mentioned.

diagnoses: Infectious Diseases (e.g., viral infections like Epstein-Barr virus, HIV)
Lupus Nephritis (if renal involvement is considered)

diagnoses.name: Adult-onset Still's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory disorder characterized by high fevers, rash, and joint pain. It may lead to chronic arthritis and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, characterized by periods of illness (flares) and wellness.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting joints, including those in the hands and feet. The autoimmune disease can cause swelling and pain, and over time, it may result in bone erosion and joint deformity.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An uncommon inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It is considered a muscular dystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis of the skin. It affects the joints and areas where ligaments and tendons attach to bone.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A condition involving joint inflammation, often in the knees, ankles, and feet, that usually occurs after an infection in another part of the body.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, characterized by fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: The most common type of arthritis in children under the age of 16, causing joint swelling, pain, and stiffness.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the development of tiny clumps of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, most commonly the lungs, lymph nodes, eyes, and skin.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A disease that causes inflammation in the walls of medium-sized arteries throughout the body, including the coronary arteries. It primarily affects children.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, Epstein-Barr virus)
